Award.AwardTitle: Variations in Claims Making and Compensation in the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
After injuries and illness, people in the United States rely upon a variety of mechanisms for compensation. People combine private insurance, public insurance, and mechanisms within the civil justice system. Earlier scholarship found relationships between the area of law and the demographic characteristics of people and claims making. In recent years there has been very little empirical scholarship on how people make claims, yet there have been substantial transformations in both the demographic characteristics of the people of the United States and in the insurance and civil justice institutions in the United States. This project will analyze how people search for compensation for losses associated with injuries and illnesses and analyze the complementary roles of various compensation institutions. The project will rely upon a probability-based Internet panel. After an initial screen, the project will select a subsample to address injuries and compensation. A better understanding of how people make claims, which systems work and in what way, how that varies by demographic characteristics, and how people understand the compensation they receive is fundamental to understanding significant social and private spending in the United States.

The questions are relevant to a broad range of public policies, including private and public social spending. The principal investigators will be able to provide information to policymakers concerning complementary mechanisms. In addition, the project will train students in methods of the social sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
.

The initial work described in this overview is designed to better understand the extent to which people use the civil justice system (courts, lawyers, liability insurers, lawsuits, informal claims, and the like) in the aftermath of what we call "significant medical conditions."  The goals included the following:

-Describe the incidence, nature, and financial and life impacts of significant illness and injuries

-Explore the roles of insurers, tort, government, and other systems in addressing these consequences

-Understand how losses affect use of civil liability system  

Our approach was simple:

-Field a "screener survey" to identify people with significant medical conditions with onset or discovery in 2017

-Follow up with a "main survey" distributed only to people reporting qualifying conditions

-Use a nationally representative probability-based Internet panel to field the screener and main surveys 

Significant illness or injury: If a panelist reported that he or she took four days or more off from their job or school, was unable to do normal home chores or take care of dependents for at least four days, visited a health care provider three or more times, spent at least one night in a health care facility, or made at least one ER visit, and if any of these events was related to the same medical condition first occurring or first discovered during 2017, then we considered the illness or injury to be a significant one for the purpose of our study (deaths, minors, and institutionalized adults were not included).

While the condition could have begun or been discovered at any point during 2017 to qualify, the events we captured in our surveys could only have taken place during a limited period from condition start through the fielding of the main survey in May 2018.  Early analysis of those results and discussions with experts in tort law and insurance led to our decision towards the end of the NSF grant period to field a previously unanticipated follow-up survey to be rolled out shortly after this report is submitted.  Thus the discussion herein only applies to our initial findings, with a much more comprehensive final publication that adds in 18 months of post-onset\discovery to be published in summer 2020.  The results described here thus are illustrative only until the final peer reviewed report is released.

We invited 27,460 members of the panel to take the screener survey.  Of those, 17,161 panelists (62.5%) completed the screener.  A key finding from the screener is that 16.7% (weighted) of adult Americans had at least one medical condition in 2017 meeting the tests described previously.

Of the 2,967 panelists qualifying in the screener, 2,456 returned for the main survey (82.8%) and reported on 2,759 distinct conditions.  We report our findings in terms of weighted conditions reported.  

Civil justice system usage: The person must have some belief that one of the underlying causes of the onset or severity of significant medical condition in question was the actions or inactions of some other individual or entity.  But some concrete steps need to actually be taken to obtain compensation (monetary damages) in order to transform those beliefs into action, such as filing a lawsuit, filing a claim with another's insurer, consulting with an attorney for advice, etc. 

About one out of five (20.5%) of those with significant medical conditions believed that a person or an entity was at least partially responsible for causing or aggravating their condition.  It turns out that relatively few actually attempt to seek compensation.  Only about 20% of these "blamers" took the specific steps we describe in our study to at least explore the possibility of recovering tort compensation (the other 80% either used the workers' compensation system exclusively or did nothing at all).  About one of 24 (4.2%) significant medical conditions involved the civil justice system in some way (we termed this group the "claimers"; some in this group also advanced a workers' compensation claim in addition to seeking tort damages).

The work goes far beyond just the assessing the size of the "blamers" and "claimers", of course.  We collected considerable information on the circumstances surrounding onset and treatment; type, severity, and short and long term impacts; financial, educational, and employment consequences; size of medical bills; availability of collateral benefit sources (such as health insurance, sick pay, disability insurance, etc.); utilization of the workers' compensation system; utilization of the civil justice system; and demographic and opinion data on the participating panelists.  We will include the critical results of the upcoming final round of surveys to our analysis and use the enhanced data for modeling how a person's background, condition severity and consequences, and availability of alternative sources for financial help factor into the decision to seek compensation through the tort liability regime. An anonymized version of the data will be submitted to ICPSR.
